# King–Nash House

| locmapin = Chicago#Illinois#USA
| area =
| built = 1901
| architect = George W. Maher
| architecture = Late 19th And Early 20th Century American Movements, Prairie School
| added = February 10, 1983
| refnum = 83000311
}}
The King–Nash House, also known as Patrick J. King House, is a combination of Sullivanesque, Colonial Revival, and Prairie styles house in the East Garfield Park area of Chicago, Illinois, United States.  The house was built in 1901 by George W. Maher for Patrick J. King. From 1925 until his death in 1943, it was home to Chicago political boss Patrick Nash.
It was listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places in 1983.  It was designated a Chicago Landmark on February 10, 1988.
Gallery
Window from the James A. Patton House MET DP207452.jpg|Louis J. Millet's thistle-designed window from the James A. Patton House designed by George Washington Maher, now in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
WLA lacma Fireplace Surround from the Patrick J King House Chicago.jpg|Fireplace Surround from the Patrick J King House in Chicago now at LACMA
